fxInfo_citation: Pemstein et al. (2018, V-Dem Working Paper Series 2018:21); V-Dem Codebook (see suggested citation at the top of this document).
fxInfo_clarification: Because discourse varies greatly from person to person, base your answer on the style that is most typical of prominent national political leaders.
fxInfo_cross_coder_aggregation: Bayesian Item Response Theory Measurement Model
fxInfo_question: When important policy changes are being considered, to what extent do political elites acknowledge and respect counterarguments?

fxInfo_responses.value: Counterarguments are not allowed or if articulated, punished.
Counterarguments are allowed at least from some parties, but almost always are ignored.
Elites tend to acknowledge counterarguments but then explicitly degrade them by making a negative statement about them or the individuals and groups that propose them.
Elites tend to acknowledge counterarguments without making explicit negative or positive statements about them.
Elites almost always acknowledge counterarguments and explicitly value them, even if they ultimately reject them for the most part.
Elites almost always acknowledge counterarguments and explicitly value them, and frequently also even accept them and change their position.

fxInfo_scale: Ordinal, converted to interval by the measurement model
